content.description: From the base of the East Face, climb into the col directly below the center of the face. The col sweeps right, then back left, ending in the saddle above the center of the East Face.
content.protection: Ice protection if you aren't comfortable soloing AI2-3

content.description: This is an alternative to the 4th Class Section of rock at the top of the East Couloir that allows one to climb the mountain mostly on snow.  Park at Horton Lake trail head and ascend the slopes leading to the East Couloir.  Ascend the couloir to the saddle.  From the saddle traverse west over class 3 rocks descending slightly until reaching a steep face of snow on the south facing slope rising above a broad chute.  Ascend until topping out just below the last 100 ft to the summit.  An easy scramble up Class 2-3 rock leads to the summit.
content.location: The North Slope toward Horton Lake is a relatively safe descent option

content.description: The prominent East Couloir of Basin Mountain rises approximately 2,000 feet to a saddle, at which point a 4th class/low 5th class scramble to the Northwest will gain the summit.
content.protection: Roping up with a leader may give confidence to a climber inexperienced on snow. Bring a light rock rack if you are uncomfortable soloing low 5th class rock.
content.location: Approach the col using an old jeep trail. You can't miss the col, it can be seen from the Buttermilks main area.

pathTokens: 07 - Humphreys Basin, Pine Creek & Granite Park
